intro: Lychnophora brunioides var. affinis, commonly known as the Brazilian rosewood, is a species of flowering plant in the family Rubiaceae. It is native to the Atlantic Forest region of Brazil and is characterized by its aromatic, dark-colored wood. The plant features opposite, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, white or pale yellow flowers. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and historical use in musical instrument crafting. However, due to overharvesting, it is now considered a threatened species.
